posts.name: WarrenR
Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
This is the pattern in C++.  Member variables are initialized in the constructor, so line 28 in the .h doesn‚Äôt do anything at all, except in the context of some constructor.  The compiler will generate an implicitly-declared default constructor, but only if no other constructor has been declared (since another constructor is declared, this won‚Äôt happen here).  Either way, only one constructor is called (although these can explicitly call each other).  So, there no reinitialization is happening.

I suppose this is why C++ has the reputation it does ‚Äì it‚Äôs actually hard to give a concise answer here, and when I went to link a page with a good explanation, most wound up using a bunch of fairly esoteric definitions.  Things have evolved, which is one reason there are multiple ways to do things.  This can result in a confusing set of choices.

posts.name: WarrenR
posts.cooked:
Thanks for your reply, but I‚Äôm still unclear on whats actually happening here.

nuttle:

The compiler will generate an implicitly-declared default constructor, but only if no other constructor has been declared (since another constructor is declared, this won‚Äôt happen here

As the only constructor in the example command class is the one that takes a parameter of pointer to a subsystem, does this mean the constructor of the class that a command is templated from (ie command helper class) is actually what runs when line 28 executes. I tried looking at that code and quickly realised that it is way outside of my understanding.  The only thing I noticed was there was directive for the compiler to supply a default constructor for zero arguments. Surely some constructor code must run when an instance of a class is declared, or wouldn‚Äôt there be some compiler error saying no instance of constructor exist that matches the arguments supplied (none in this case)?

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
It‚Äôs more the case that line 28 never executes, it‚Äôs just defining the data structure which is used to hold instances of that class.  When the constructor code executes, it has to take care of initializing member variables.  In C++, the compiler often takes care of a lot of this and so it‚Äôs sometimes hard to follow; there are rules on initializing each data member that depend on the type, any initializer code in the declaration, the constructor being executed, etc.

And, when an instance of a class is initialized, the compiler picks which constructor to call based on any arguments supplied.  In this case, it is the constructor which takes a subsystem parameter.  But, again, it isn‚Äôt the declaration which causes the constructor to be called in this example.  Let me see if I can find a good explanation to link‚Ä¶

EDIT: Classes (I) - C++ Tutorials covers this and it‚Äôs fairly concise.  However, it does use C++ terms with very specific meanings, so one has to read carefully.

Line 7 of the header is the constructor for RobotContainer , it takes no arguments and initializes m_autonomousCommand by passing m_subsystem.  Because m_subsystem was declared ahead of m_autonomousCommand, it has already been initialized at that point (by calling ExampleSubsystem() ).

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
There is only one ‚Äúinitialization‚Äù, and that is on line 7 of the RobotContainer.cpp file. Line 28 of the RobotContainer.h file is a ‚Äúdeclaration‚Äù. While the specifics can vary language to language, Declaring a variable is when you give or ‚Äúdeclare‚Äù the type and name of a variable, so the program can allocate the memory to store/track that reference. initialization is when you actually put or assign data to that reference.

So in the header file RobotContainer.h where you define the class‚Äôs members (methods and variables) is saying "hey, RobotContainer objects have a private variable called m_autonomousCommand that is of type ExampleCommand ".

Then the RobotContainer.cpp file says "When you execute the constructor method to make a RobotContainer object, initialize the m_autonomousCommand variable with a new ExampleCommand object passing the reference to m_subsystem .

Many languages, C++ included, usually allow you to combine the declaration and initialization, ie int i = 0; , but the C convention has generally been to declare all your variables before using them, to the point of putting those declarations in a separate ‚Äúheader‚Äù file separate from the implementation code. This convention has held over to C++ classes.

As for the specific syntax of having this initiation after a colon in the constructor reference, as opposed to being in the body of the constructor, I‚Äôm not familiar with this syntax, and am not regularly a C++ developer. So I can‚Äôt answer why it is specifically done that way.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: C++'s delegated constructor syntax is important because the constructors are called before any code runs .  It is important to note the difference between assignment and initialization here - the delegated constructor performs initialization , and anything after that will be assignment .  In C++ these are different operations!
